paragraphs.name: 3cf3
paragraphs.text: Regenerative cultures are cultures of empathy
Conversation between Edwin Rutsch and Daniel Wahl

In late October, Edwin Rutsch — the founder of ‘The Centre for Building a Culture of Empathy’ — invited me to an interview about the relationship between my own approach to ‘Designing Regenerative Cultures’ and his organization’s work on establishing cultures of empathy.

We cover a lot of ground in this 85 minute conversation. Straight from Edwin’s introduction we launch into exploring the centrality of our lived experience of interbeing in nested wholeness as a way of deepening into empathy with the world that brings us forth.

paragraphs.name: f88f
paragraphs.text: The need to reconnect with all life as the ground of our being and the ability to ‘feel with’ other humans and with the wider community of life will both play important roles in co-creating regenerative cultures everywhere.

paragraphs.name: 896b
paragraphs.text: Edwin invites me to reflect on the role of cooperation and competition over the course of evolution. We need to put these two ways of interacting within the wider community of life into right proportions. The major jumps in evolution have primarily been catalysed by the integration of diversity at high levels of complexity through new forms for cooperation.

paragraphs.name: afbd
paragraphs.text: Edwin and I also explore the persistence of the story of separation — between nature and culture — as one of the key influences on how we still experience our lives and interpret our experience today. The need to overcome the Cartesian split has been mentioned for decades as being central to the next step in our cultural evolution and yet we are still very much in its grip.

paragraphs.name: f5ef
paragraphs.text: The conversation was really rich and Edwin’s attempts to mirror back what he heard me say always prompted me into another loop in a deepening spiral in which we touch on ‘species extinction and a sense of numbness in the face of loss’; the importance of ‘facing uncertainty’ head on and getting used to it as part of the pain that cracks the shell of our understanding; the way that confrontation with our own mortality is waking us up to life; the importance of rite of passage in indigenous cultures and how we are undergoing a species level rite of passage; how we are being inducted into the reciprocity and co-creation of being a mature member of the tribe of life.

paragraphs.name: bfe1
paragraphs.text: Edwin and I explored how the very immenence of civilizational collapse and ecosystems collapse might bring us back into a sensed, embodied, felt (survival mode) of understanding that we are life. Life’s role is to create conditions conducive to life. That is our deeper and higher calling.

paragraphs.name: 527d
paragraphs.text: Since we left doing the appropriate thing for so long, we now need to spend 20 to 30 years in unprecendented efforts to heal ecosystems — bioregion by bioregion — in the intention to heal the Earth. In this very process we will heal oursleves and heal humanity. In part, maturation will come from having to sustain efforts while not knowing whether we will make it for most of that time.

paragraphs.name: eeac
paragraphs.text: Coming back to the moment — to NOW — again to reconnect to place and the beauty of the relationships. The relational magic of being in connection, co-creation and exchange with people and more than human nature right in front of us — appreactiate beauty again — unfolding our potential to become healing keystone species in the ecosystems we inhabit and become stewards in the way that indigenous people understand this notion. We need to reindigenize into the places we inhabit!

We also explore how empathic dialogue can serve as a methodology and Edwin explains how he has worked with this and is trying to bring this practice to the ‘regenerative culture’ groups of many XR (Extinction Rebellion) groups around the US and internationally.

This leads us to highlight the link between this ‘empathic dialogue’ approach and the ancient practice of ‘The Way of Council’. A practice connected to the ancient wisdom of asking ‘how does it serve my self, my people, and the community of life?’ A practice that invites self care as a means to be of better service beyond oneself. A practice of deep listening from the heart to the wisdom of the collective mind and of spirit.

We speak about the important framing by Joanna Macy that we are to play a dual role of being at one and the same time hospice workers of a dying system and midwives of a new world — a new way of being in the world — that wants to be born trough us and within us.

paragraphs.name: fc13
paragraphs.text: I also mention briefly my meeting with Barry Kerzin’s — the personal physician of the Dalai Lama — and how his work on empathy and compassion in medicine has helped to transform the practice of many health care professionals in the United States and suggest to Edwin to explore Barry’s work as a possible inspiration or link to the work of his centre.

paragraphs.name: 8f56
paragraphs.text: … as you can see, we had a rich conversation.
